title: Open Source Maintenance Burden
context: Companies open-source their internal tools to build community, attract talent, and establish technical credibility. The launch gets stars, blog posts, and conference talks. But open-source maintenance is a permanent commitment that most organizations underestimate. Issues pile up. PRs from external contributors need review. Security vulnerabilities need patching. Documentation needs updating. The maintainers — usually the original authors — burn out within 1-2 years. The project enters a zombie state: too popular to abandon, too costly to maintain. Meanwhile, the company's internal fork diverges from the open-source version, creating two codebases to maintain. The community that was supposed to contribute becomes a support burden, filing issues faster than the team can triage them.
hypothesis: Open sourcing builds community and reduces maintenance through contributions.

effects.label: Maintenance burden exceeds contribution value
effects.impact: 90% of PRs need significant rework or rejection

children.label: External PRs require extensive review and context-sharing
Feature requests diverge from internal needs
Emotional toll of community management underestimated
Internal features can't be open-sourced (proprietary dependencies)
Community features don't meet internal quality bar

dontIf: You don't have dedicated maintainer time budgeted beyond the initial launch
Your internal version will diverge significantly from what you open-source
ifYouMust: Budget 30-50% of a full-time engineer for maintenance before launching
Set clear contribution guidelines and scope boundaries from day one
Plan for maintainer rotation to prevent burnout
Define an explicit end-of-life policy for when the project is no longer maintained

alternatives.note: Fund existing projects rather than creating new ones
